    <item>
      <title><![CDATA[Decades-old IT Act no longer fit for creator economy, say experts]]></title>
      <link><![CDATA[https://www.cnbctv18.com/videos/business/india-digital-platforms-revenue-sharing-content-creators-ashwini-vaishnaw-experts-19858823.htm]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[As the government sharpens its message to digital platforms on sharing revenues with content creators, legal and industry voices say India’s existing framework is ill-equipped for the realities of today’s creator economy. Anupam Shukla, Partner at Pioneer Legal, argues that the decades-old IT Act offers little protection to millions of creators generating value for global platforms, forcing India to look at models from Europe and Australia. Sanjay Wadhwa, representing the Indian music industry, says platforms have long relied on safe harbour provisions to minimise payouts, starving creators and rights holders of capital needed to invest in new content. Both agree that standardised, law-backed mechanisms—rather than fragmented contracts—may be the only way to ensure a fair and sustainable sharing of revenues in the digital age.]]></description>
      <pubDate><![CDATA[Thu, 26 Feb 2026 18:11:00 +0530]]></pubDate>
      <dc:creator>Swapnil Deshpande</dc:creator>
      <guid><![CDATA[https://www.cnbctv18.com/videos/business/india-digital-platforms-revenue-sharing-content-creators-ashwini-vaishnaw-experts-19858823.htm]]></guid>

    </item>
